segments.text: Yeah, it is.
She did a good job.
Okay, this is Ron Shoring in Kingsville, Texas, interviewing Don Yeomans.
Don, for the record, what's your name and date and place of birth?
Donald Keith Yeomans.
I was born in Rochester, New York, May 3, 1942.
How'd you get interested in astronomy?
Well, I don't think it started until I was...
halfway through my undergraduate career at the Middlebury College in Vermont.
And I took an undergraduate course in astronomy from my professor, who turned out to be very contagious and his enthusiasm for astronomy.
I think it started there, really.
So I had been taking math as an undergraduate and have a math major.
But I took a number of physics courses after that and astronomy, and then went on
the University of Maryland to do graduate school work.
Why did you pick Maryland?
Well, they had an excellent program.
I interviewed with a number of schools, but Maryland had an excellent program.
They offered me more money, and they were one of the closer schools to where I was living in Rochester.
What was your specialty in, I mean your specialty is commons now, but was it when you were grad student?
At the University of Maryland we were, everyone took a lot of radio astronomy, astrophysics, solar astronomy,
almost everything except what I finally wound up in, which was dynamical astronomy.
So we had a very broad background in most of the astronomical subjects.

My dynamical work really was done by Peter Musen at the Goddard Space Flight Center, who was sort of an adjunct professor at the University of Maryland, and he taught a number of us several years of dynamical astronomy.
What was your thesis on?
It was on the non-gravitational forces on the comets.
Jacques Beniziner was the example I used.
But I developed numerical integration routines and differential correction routines to determine the cometary orbits.
and including the so-called non-gravitational effects, which had recently been detected by Brian Martin in the motions of many of his comments.
Well, they weren't recently detected.
Actually, they were detected way back when.
Ain't thinking.
But Brian had recently modeled those in a fairly comprehensive fashion.
So I used that model and then predicted some meteor showers
for that particular comet.
The draconids, of course, meteor showers are associated with that kind of thing.
So I went back and investigated the circumstances of the previous shower phenomena and went ahead and made predictions for the future.
How did they turn out?
Well, predicting meteor showers is a whole lot different than
predicting the return of the continents.
We thought there would be quite a substantial shower in 1955.
There was not.
Almost exactly a century after the failure of 1865.
Yeah.
So I have since gotten away from meteor shower prediction, pretty much, and stuck with trying to predict the motions in the last two weeks of college.
When did you, by the way, when did you get your bachelor's and when did you get your PhD?
I got the master's in 1967 and the PhD in 1970 at the University of Maryland.
Where did you then go to work after you got your degree?
Even as a graduate student, I was doing some work at the Goddard Space Flight Center, which is very close to the University of Maryland, of course.
Again, working with Peter Musen doing some computations.
And after graduating from the University of Maryland, I actually had a job briefly with the Bendix Field Engineering Corporation.
They were contracting with Goddard.
And later, with Computer Sciences Corporation, again, contracting for Goddard.
And at both places, I was really working
Bob Farquhar, who now is at the Applied Physics Lab, but his interest then, and in fact now, is fly-by missions to comets and asteroids.
And so I started off working in the field that I'd been trained in, which is sort of unusual.
And I've been doing the motions of comets and asteroids primarily for
for mission analysis work and mission planning ever since.
After those couple of short stints, where did you go?
In 1976, I was asked by Lou Friedman to come out to the Depth Propulsion Laboratory, which I did, and I've been there ever since.
Do you think planetary astronomy is real astronomy?
or planetary science?
Well, I certainly do, yes.
But I think your question derives from the fact that the majority of the astronaut community probably doesn't feel that way.
I was going to ask you that.
That's certainly been the universal, I've interviewed 30 people in the whole 30 degrees.
Do you think, in the time since you've been in the field,
the situation has gotten better and planetary astronomy has a better holder among stellar and galactic astronomers than you see?
I think it does, yes.
And why?
Well, I was just going to say, primarily because of NASA and the exploration, planetary exploration program within NASA.
Planetary astronomy very much holds its own, especially with
Well, but the perception, I think, is strong.
I think it's at least an equal footing now.
And perhaps I just want a little bit to quote the monetary strongest side, at least from my very biased point of view.
When you were getting started, did you feel inferior to, say, people who observed the 200-inch galaxy?
My background really was not smack in the middle of planetary astronomy.
It was sort of halfway between planetary astronomy and dynamical astronomy.
So I never had the impression that I was inferior to the stellar astronomers because I never considered myself a traditional astronomer in the first place.
My discipline was halfway between planetary astronomy and dynamical astronomy.
So I really never had that perception or that feeling.
Here's a question that I know you know the answer to, and I do too.
But it seems that in the 20s, 30s, and 40s, when very little serious astrophysics was done in the solar system, the comets were immune for this.
The cometary papers would appear in the anthrax.
Is that, am I correct in saying that?
Yeah, I think that's true.
There was some excellent work done by spectroscopists, as you well know, in the 40s.
And even prior to that, the spectroscopy of meteors was important work.
Well, comets, I think, have always retained sort of a mysterious bent to them.
Any information that could be gleaned using astrophysical techniques was applied.
They did work on polarization studies of comets and spectroscopic work, electric work, infrared.
Whenever a new technique was developed, it wasn't long before they would apply it to comets as well as some other astrophysical objects.
I'd like to ask you your opinions about some things relating to comets.
When do you think photometry became good enough to actually tell us something about the comet?
Well, I think there was some excellent work done in the late 19th century, really.
I think that's when it started.
There were a series of photometric observations made of comets, and that data is often used even today in an effort to discern whether comets are fading as a function of time or whether they're
Spectroscopy
Continuous spectra, continuous spectra, however the photography came in and showed Brown-Huckaboo and certainly confirmed the polarization work that showed the polar dust.
And then, of course, the first, I guess, Huggins saw emission law.
But for a long time it was held up, I guess, because, in fact, a lot of mechanics hadn't been invented and people didn't know what to make.
That's right.
Yeah, that's true.
There was a lot of spectroscopic work done, again, in the
late 19th century, early 20th century, but apart from a couple of initial breakthroughs where they, was it C2?
Yeah.
And that was, you mentioned that Huggins was lucky, or is it you?
Well, that's true.
I didn't mention it, but yeah, the C2 lines were some of the, a couple of the lines that he actually could identify without any knowledge of the,
And he did.
He actually had a carbon arc made through the telescope, and he practically analyzed that and looked at some emission lines from Comets and correctly identified these lines as due to carbon.
But that was the exception.
As you noted, the quantum mechanics didn't come in until the very 20th century, and it was then that all of these spectral lines and bands that have been noted were properly identified.
You've done this in your book, but this is for the record.
Could you kind of give a short summary of how cometary astronomy developed from, say, 1860

Well, in terms of motions of comets, you noted that Encke detected these so-called non-gravitational effects in the early 19th century with the comet that now bears his name, and of course he initially attributed this to the
the drag effects of the ether.
And so that was a bit of a backwards step.
And that result was so well verified and in place that the notion of this interplanetary ether continued well into the late 19th century because of that.
So that was a bit of a step backwards.
Another step backwards, I think, was the, well,

An unfortunate relationship between the observed meteor showers in the 1860s, the Leonids and Perseids were identified by Schiaparelli and a few others as being due to their parent comets, the Comet Swift tunnel, the Temple Tunnel.
And this association between meteor streams and comets sort of evolved into the flying dust bank model of a comet.
And that was unfortunate.
The association of meteor streams with comets was very fortunate.
That was a major step forward.
But the further inference that somehow comets were clouds of particles flying in formation was a notion that held center stage to the 1950 high-speed conglomerate model.
Then there was some work done in the 1900s and 1901 on light pressure and the fact that light pressure could affect dust particles.
Of course, Amelia Lynn lends itself to the notion of dust-tales being formed by the pressure of sunlight.
It wasn't until many years later that the correct explanation for the ion-tales was denoted as, for many years, light pressure was vibrated, for the most part.
was applied in an attempt to explain the Type I, Type II, and Type III tails.
Now, the Type I was the dust tail, and the Type II tails were the ion tails.
But, of course, he lumped them together and tried to explain both with light pressure and, of course, was unsuccessful.

at least the type 1 dust tails were successfully explained by the pressure of sunlight and it wasn't until the solar wind notion was put forward by Biermann and also around 1950 that the charge exchange mechanism between cometary ions and the solar
plasma fails radiating outward from the sun at 400 kilometers a second was successfully used to explain the ion fails.
You had mentioned the emission lines from the spectra were noted as early as, I think it was 1880s, 1860s, 1870s, 1880s.
Emission lines, emission bands were detected

and it was generally assumed that these were, well, some of them were carbon and were identified as such, but most of them were simply noted as mysterious features that couldn't be identified chemically because the quantum mechanics hadn't been invented yet.
Now, in terms of

there was all kinds of attempts to do this photometrically, but the problem there was that the dust contamination to the photometric solutions was always a problem, and so these things were considered to be far larger than they really were.
Elizabeth Romer did some interesting work back in the 60s where she very carefully tried to subtract, or she took
and derived some fairly decent estimates for the sizes of the nucleons themselves, but even her estimates were somewhat contaminated by the dust.
And it really wasn't until the 70s when there was a reasonable estimate
And pretty much they lie in the range from 5 to 10 to 20 kilometers, that range.
I have a personal bone to pick, so I'll pick it.
Well, not pick, but to emphasize.
A long time before they identified water vapor as a major constituent of comets, for some time before, it became kind of popular to think that they were, even though we didn't have the evidence.
Do you remember when that happened, or did you find it out when you were working on your book?
Well, of course, Fred Whipple, in his model of 1950, postulated water is one of the major icy constituents that warms methane and ammonia.
Now, the next step forward in terms of water ice, I think, was taken with the
the above-the-atmosphere rocket flight, they were doing ultraviolet observations of the enormous clouds of hydrogen surrounding these clouds.
That was a big surprise to everyone, just to see how large these clouds of light and alpha clouds of hydrogen were.
And, of course, it wasn't that big a leap to note that one way of getting these enormous clouds of hydrogen
to vaporize water and ionize it.
So that was another step toward water and vaporizing.
And then there was some, of course, the commonality of flybys, maybe six of the others, because they directly observed water vaporization.
But there were some pretty strong hints even before that, well before that, about water vaporization.
How would you contrast planetary astronomy in 1970 with what it is today in 1974?
Well, in 1970, I just got out of school, and it was sort of the Apollo program that had pumped a lot of interest and a lot of money into the field.
And so it was the heyday.
It wasn't the last day.
In the 70s, there was a wave of enthusiasm because of .
There's no question .
when you're riding the coattails.
To a certain extent, planetary astronomy isn't riding the coattails of manned space like even today.
But I think the Apollo program certainly sparked it.
And then the Viking missions were exciting because of the hope of finding some sort of life on Mars.
The Voyager program was extraordinary.
of each new planet as the Voyagers want to have .

But the Vikings and the Voyagers are come and gone, and now we're back to almost where we were prior to the Apollo program, not in terms of , but in terms of not having any major missions to explore except for .
What do you think the state of planetary astronomy today is, and what's your guess for the immediate future, the next five or ten years?
Well, I'm not too confident that the next five or ten years, frankly,
From my limited point of view, being at JPL, there is Cassini, which is supporting a quarter of the laboratory.
And there seems to be a perception, really, that we're going now into smaller emissions, hopefully more frequently.
Smaller, better, faster, cheaper.
The motto that Stan Gold has been
And so from JPL's point of view, where we once had a monopoly, of course, that's no longer the case.
So you've got universities participating in the discovery program.
You've got APL.
You've got DOD participating in some of that.
So in terms of a JPL employee in planetary science, it's going to be a little rough.
Going back 25 years ago, there was no such journal as the American Astronomical Society, or I should say 30 years ago, and there was no division for planetary sciences.
Now planetary workers have their own journals and their own division of the American Astronomical Society.
Do you think those two developments, both as it relates to planetary astronomy and astronomy in general, were good, bad, or just inevitable?
Oh, they're very good and inevitable.
The Division of Planetary Sciences is extremely active.
It's by far my favorite meeting, even more interesting to me than this one, the Division of Planetary Sciences,
DPS encompasses not only dynamics, but it has physics, you have spectroscopy, you have words, you have dynamics.
It's a great place to get together with people with diverse backgrounds.
It's marvelous.
And I'm extremely well-attended to it.
It's huge.
It's very private.
And Icarus, likewise, has done a marvelous job.
Where do you think planetary science would be today in the USA?
I hesitate to think where we would be without NASA.
Again, the Apollo program, I think, kicked us into high gear.
In fact, you could make an argument for NASA, the space program, actually giving birth to the planetary science community up in North America.
As you're probably aware, before there was a NASA
A fair amount of research was sponsored by the Department of Defense, Stellar and Galactic Astronomy by the Office of Naval Research, but planetary and lunar was by the Air Force.
There's talk of doing away with NASA.
What would your opinion be of working for the Air Force?
Actually, I am working for the Air Force.
At the moment, I have a small contract working on Dave Rappaport's summer development for common ground.
I don't think that would be a healthy situation.
The Air Force really has a very limited interest in monetary science and science in general.
I don't see that being an option.
doing away with NASA and transferring it to Air Force or whatever DOD branches would be very wise.
How do you think NASA handles management today and when you first started thinking about it or experiencing it?
Well, the management of scientific contracts.
Oh, I see.
Well, I've had a contract with NASA.

under the rtop program i've never had a problem there's always the problem that the money available is far less than what is required but that's a continual problem because even if the money doesn't decrease the number of people buying that thing is increasing
The science management at NASA has been, in my opinion at least, pretty good.
I suspect that's not a popular opinion.
I may be the only one holding that opinion, but I have never had a problem with the review of the proposals,
I've had a very positive reaction.
All right, we've visited all the planets with Pluto at least once now.
We got to look at their satellites and so forth.
And no trace of life or anything approaching it has been found anywhere in the solar system except Earth.
Do you think this has had an impressing effect on public interest and budgets for quantitary sites, or not?
Well, initially there was a great deal of talk about finding a place on Mars, and I think that fueled a lot of the public interest that led to the successful biking and the Voyager program.
But I think that the population is sophisticated enough to realize that
that life is something that's prevalent on Mars or any of the planets that exist.
I'd like to think they're educated enough to realize that, well, I like to turn it around, that why is it that life has been about Earth and hasn't yet been discovered anywhere else?
That, to me, is everybody's exciting finding life elsewhere.
The thought that we're possibly a fluke.
of interstellar accidents is maybe more interesting ultimately than planning to land on Mars, which didn't happen.
I think if we're going to relate, or try and regain the public interest in space, our efforts can't be focused upon life, because we're going to have to

It's going to have to be the expansion of the discovery of new neighborhoods, new possibilities, doing this for the next generation, and finding new resources to explore the planetary realm first, and then out from there.
So no, I don't think it's .
Since we don't know if it's going to be an informed guess, do you think comments are leftovers from the formation of the solar system or have the ones we see now been somehow acquired by ourselves?
The consensus view certainly is that comets are the leftover bits and pieces from the solar system formation process.
I think that's probably the correct interpretation.
If we were actively acquiring comets from elsewhere, we would see comets on parabolic orbits.
We would see hyperbolic orbits.
And we don't.
We don't see hyperbolic orbits, strong anechoic orbits at all.
So yeah, I think kind of the leftovers from the outer solar system formation process, I mean, chemically they're very similar to the outer planets.
That's very good.
Leftovers from the inner solar system formation process, they're very similar.
I think that aspect is fairly well be the case.
As you're well aware, the Division for Planetary Sciences is quite active in lobbying Congress.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job in presenting their case to Congress?
I think they've started to lobby, and that's an excellent start, but we haven't done nearly as much.

As you get older and more cynical, you realize that the views you held as a youth, that is, the science is so interesting and physically means that Congress will see our point of view and appropriate the necessary funds.
It's simply too naive.
It didn't work for higher-engine particle physicists, that's for sure.
No, we have to get in there and we have to bang on doors.
We have to mount...
a write-in campaign for particular issues that we feel strongly about.
We have to get to the representatives and make sure that they understand how we feel and just flex our muscles and throw our weight around it.
It's the only way we're going to make any progress.
Do you think Planetary Astronomers have done a good job in selling themselves to the public?
It's almost as if astronomers and scientists don't have the time to share it with the people who are paying for their power.
We really have dropped the ball on that part.
We should be out there at the high schools doing talks.
We should be out there at the adult clubs.
We remain in the excitement of our science, the people who are paying the bills.
And as a rule, the commons and scientists in general don't do that well, and they don't do it properly.
We have guys like Carl Sagan who do it very well.
But we have to get more of us out there.

relay the excitement of our science to them and every time they give a talk we should thank them for the privilege of working for them they really have to do much here's a personal question what's the best piece of work well uh i guess it would have to be uh things not a particular thing but uh
What we do at JPL within my little group is
is when NASA wants to send a spacecraft by documentary center, by comet Halley, by asteroid Ida or Gaspra, they have to know where these objects are in space.
So it's our job to get the necessary reference star catalogs to experience the observers, generate the orbital updates and the tremor adaptations and the air analyses that allow the spacecraft

I think that's the thing I'm most proud of, is that for every object, for every comet and asteroid that a spacecraft has encountered, it was our efforts that told them where to, where the topics were.
We've done a pretty good job so far.
What was the most fun?
I think working during the comet Halley and working with the Russians.
the Soviets, as they went in, was a real eye-opener.
And seeing the way they did business, contrasting it with the way we did business, and their facilities and computers versus ours, and their ideas versus ours, I thought that was fascinating.
They really had a marvelous time.
Ever had any misfires or dead ends?
I was investigating the motion of asteroid Icarus in 1566.
And we knew that it was affected by relativistic effects, of course, because it is such an elliptic orbit, it's such a small, so many directions, just like the sea.
the orbit of Mercury rotates in terms of the gravitational effect, and so does the orbit of Mercury.

And we had put those effects in our code, and we still had some problems with the observations, so we solved for some cometary non-gravitational effects, and that seemed to take care of things, and so we made the inference that, yes indeed, this is a comet that is still outgassing, and
And that was why these effects were noticeable.
Well, after publishing it, it turns out we had a bug in the program, and then the relativistic effects were not being applied at all.
And once that bug was declared, the motion of the attitude was explained very well without any kind of
When you're sitting on a plane or waiting in line or something, just an expert who's not a scientist, finds out what you do for a living, what's their attitude?
Well, it's a little, I won't say they're awestruck, but the conversation seems to stop
rather abruptly when they realized that this person was an astronomer.
They know very little about it, and I guess they don't know what to talk about next.
It's not a subject that the public is as well versed in, and that's another problem.
We have to make an effort to get the public up to speed on astronomy and do fast-breaking science here.
What's the most common question people ask you?
They asked me a question about the astronomical topics they've read most recently in the newspaper.
I mean, our science does get a fair amount of press, especially with respect to the other sciences, because there's always something new going on.
A new quasar, or a new cometary phenomena, or a discovery of possible dark matter,
There's always something exotic on the fringe that sort of brings a lot of media.
That's what they usually ask about.
The most recent discovery they read about in the newspaper.
So it's imperative that we all, no matter what field we're in, that we all keep abreast of the entire astronomical literature.
um that brings up the question of do you have much contact with stellar and galactic astronomy types not on a professional level hardly ever because i mean if you go to the dps
You interact with planetary science.
If you go to the AIS meeting, you interact with galactic solar astronomers, but not planetary science.
So there's almost a complete segregation now.
Well, it's too late to ask the participants, so I've been asking planetary scientists who are around today.
Somewhere between 1900 and World War I, planetary astronomy died loudly.
Who or what killed it?
The new astronomy killed it.
The spectroscopes came online, and the search for the big question, how big was the galaxy?
Were there island universes apart from our own?
What were the constituents of the stars and galaxies?
What was the age of the universe?
The big question sort of dwarfed
There have been a lot of new discoveries and insights about the solar system in the last 25 years.
What do you think the most important one has been to the public?
To the public?
Well, I think the fact that we didn't find life on Mars is certainly important to the public.
very aware of what is
I saw a number of people that mentioned the photograph taken while we were in orbit, the photograph of the rising sun.
The idea that we are in a very small second-rate planet going around a very small second-rate sun
If we go ahead 50 years and look back, that would be the paradigm in which that would be identified.
The homocentric view that we all have of the earth is pretty much all there is to it.
As a planetary astronomer, what do you think, from your point of view, of planetary science has been the most important?
Well, from my narrow perspective, I think
Another paradigm, which recently, the last 10 years, concerning the low island impact, literally the impact of one body upon another.
When I first started out in the field,
There was a feeling that everything evolved very slowly.
There were tremendously long time scales.
In biology, things evolved according to the Darwinian theories.
Very slight changes were retained if they were helpful.
And likewise in the solar system, things evolved ever so slowly.
But I think we're getting an increasing realization that
uh...
major results will be coming out.
